The visiting side have relied on their defence and counter-attacks.

Whereas the strategy of the away side was a bit risky and reliant on solid defending to dispossess the opponent and break fast.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In an exciting Premier League clash, Chelsea played host to West Bromwich Albion at Stamford Bridge, resulting in a thrilling 2-2 draw. The match had all the elements of classic English football – intensity, skill, defensive errors, and moments of brilliance on both ends. 

As the first half commenced, West Brom kicked off proceedings. Chelsea quickly looked to assert their dominance, and within the first two minutes, they had their first shot off target. Despite the early scare, West Brom attempted to navigate through Chelsea’s pressing game, launching a series of clearances and throw-ins to relieve pressure. Both teams struggled to maintain possession early on, with numerous throw-ins and clearances as the game tried to settle into a rhythm.

Chelsea managed to get another shot off target around the 7th minute, symbolic of their attacking intent. However, West Brom held their ground defensively, with notable interventions, including a clearance and a notable effort by Gareth McAuley to tackle and disrupt Chelsea’s fluidity. The first significant passage of play saw Chelsea being awarded a free kick in the 10th minute after a foul by West Brom’s McAuley. 

As the game progressed, Chelsea showed their prowess on the ball with Willian and Cesc Fabregas orchestrating play. Fabregas, in particular, displayed his vision and passing range, almost creating an opportunity for Diego Costa, whose touch, unfortunately, let him down, enabling West Brom to regain possession. Chelsea’s persistence paid off in the 19th minute when Branislav Ivanovic delivered a precise pass into the box. Cesar Azpilicueta made no mistake, slotting the ball into the back of the net to put Chelsea 1-0 up.

West Brom responded with resilience, not allowing Chelsea to settle into their lead. Craig Gardner epitomized this spirit with a fantastic strike from 22 meters out to level the scores at 1-1. This goal brought West Brom back into the game and exemplified their capacity to capitalize from set-pieces and long-range efforts.

The remainder of the first half saw an ebb and flow of play. Chelsea enjoyed more possession, methodically passing the ball around, waiting for the right moment to penetrate West Brom’s defense. Players such as Oscar and Mikel had efforts either off-target or smothered by West Brom’s defensive setup. On the other side, West Brom managed to disrupt Chelsea’s flow with well-timed clearances and diligent defending. Darren Fletcher and Claudio Yacob were particularly notable for their attempts to control the ball in the middle of the park and push the team forward.

Both teams entered the break with the scores tied at 1-1, reflecting a balanced half with opportunities and stellar moments on both sides. The half-time break offered the teams a chance to regroup and strategize for the second half.

Chelsea made an immediate change at half-time, with Guus Hiddink bringing on Kenedy in place of Pedro, aiming to inject more pace and creativity. Chelsea resumed the second half with clear intent and quickly earned a corner. Despite repeated efforts, including a promising header from Oscar, the fortress-like defense of West Brom held firm.

In what was a physical and hard-fought encounter, the match saw frequent fouls and bookings. Diego Costa earned himself a yellow card for a late challenge early into the second half. West Brom did not relent either, making tactical substitutions to keep up with Chelsea’s pace. Saido Berahino replaced Claudio Yacob, indicating an attacking shift to try and snatch a late winner.

West Brom’s strategy seemingly paid off later into the half. However, it was an unfortunate error on their part that gifted Chelsea another lead. Gareth McAuley, under pressure, accidentally directed the ball into his net following an attacking move by Chelsea, resulting in a 2-1 scoreline.

The drama did not end there. West Brom showed remarkable resilience once more. Just moments after conceding, Stephane Sessegnon played a crucial role in maintaining the pressure, and ultimately it was James McClean, who found the equalizer. McClean seized an opportunity from just outside the box, his precision strike finding the bottom right corner to even the scores at 2-2.

The game continued with intense exchanges, both sides pushing for a late winner. Tactical fouls and set-pieces became the order of the closing minutes as both teams navigated through the tension-packed finale. Despite some last-ditch efforts and well-deserved corners won by both sides, neither Chelsea nor West Brom managed to break the deadlock.

Chelsea’s players like, Oscar, Diego Costa, and Willian were continually probing the West Brom defense. At the same time, West Brom showcased sheer determination and tactical discipline, especially their goalkeeper Myhill making crucial saves to keep his team in the contest.

As the final whistle blew, the scoreline read 2-2, a fair reflection of the contentious and well-balanced duel that both teams put up. The 40,945 fans in attendance were treated to a roller-coaster of emotions encapsulated by individual brilliance and team effort. This result meant Chelsea remained in the mix for European spots, while West Brom took home a valuable point in their fight to avoid relegation. 

Post-match reviews praised both teams for their performances. Chelsea was commended for their attacking play and possession game. Still, questions arose about their defensive stability. West Brom earned accolades for their resolute defending, quick counter-attacks, and their never-say-die attitude. Both managers pointed out the positives and the areas for improvement, but undoubtedly, it was one of those games where football was the biggest winner.

The game was a clear testament to the competitive nature of the Premier League, where on any given day, a match could swing in any direction despite what the stats might suggest. Chelsea’s ability to maintain possession and create multiple chances highlighted their attacking prowess. In contrast, West Brom’s capability to absorb pressure and strike back on opportunistic moments reaffirmed their fighting spirit.

In conclusion, Chelsea’s clash with West Brom was an early year spectacle, leaving fans and pundits alike with talking points, memorable moments, and a solid showcase of football from both sides. The 2-2 draw at Stamford Bridge was a fitting outcome for a game rich in competitive spirit and tactical spats, a reminder of why the Premier League continues to be revered globally for its unparalleled excitement and unpredictability.
